Hi Ron,

 

It still could have a Tokugawa/Matsudaira connection, they just=
 weren=92t
samurai anymore, but that should not stop someone from putting t=
heir mon on
their sword=92s habaki. Also, your point about gendai is very i=
mportant as
that is just what it is. Any blade made after the haitonorei or=
 banning the
wearing of swords is a gendai. A gendai and a gunto are not th=
e same thing.

 

Gordon

Thanks everyone, for your imput about this mon habaki on my Ya=
mon Naokatsu
katana. Soon after I sent out this question it dawned on me th=
at by Meiji 4
the Tokugawa were no longer in power and therefore, a meaning=
ful connection
between this sword and the Tokugawa would be unlikely. But I=
'm glad I asked
since this did bring about some on-line discussion. 

Inter=
estingly, this sword which was owned for years by a good friend and
eventua=
lly came to me last year, looks and feels much like a gendaito which
I gues=
s, it really is when you think about it. It is a very stoutly build
and ver=
y masculine blade although made relatively short in length (63.7 cm).
My ot=
her nidai Naokatsu which is dated 1865 is more a Nambokucho copy,
measuring=
 77.9 cm with O-gissaki. I find it interesting to see the
comparison in so =
few years but at a time of great "change" in Japan. It does
surprise me tha=
t Naokatsu still had a patron at this time of change in
power. 

Ron
